/COMMIT_MSG.message:
At least with mysql, we may be splitting hairs here, and to be honest, I'm not sure it's worth the complexity.

Looking at the query plan in mysql for both the openstack and zuul tenants, mysql always says it's going to examine more rows if I add a minimum.  In the best case, it's about 2x the number of rows.  In some cases, it's much more.

Since the query is already sorted descending, both the estimated and actual runtimes should be very close for page 1, then theoretically adding the minimum should gain an advantage as we go to more and more pages, as we don't need to gather as many items past our limit.  However, the database is already smart enough not to gather more items past our limit, so there really isn't an optimization to be made there.  They both run in a range of 0.00 to 0.02 seconds; effectively immeasurable under these conditions.

And indeed, if I run the query with an offset of 20000, it takes 2.5 seconds with the minimum, and 1.86 seconds without -- confirming what the query planner estimates -- it's more work to add the minimum check.

But there are a lot of variables; is there a situation where you have confirmed better performance?

The commit message didn't mention that.  Using this without the offset does make a difference in query time.  Times remain about the same at page 1, but offset times increase with more pages and min/max times stay constant.

I still have questions about how that will actually work (what happens when you're on page 2 and you hit back and there are more than 1 page worth of new builds on page 1?).  But we can address those later.

When crawling the builds, it can be error prone to rely on skip/limit when new builds are added between the queries, resulting in duplicated result. If I understand correctly, using the idx would ensure consistent result.

This code has actually changed, although you can't see it here because the revert is based directly on the original patch from a few months ago. Here's what it looks like now:

# Migrate database and exit if KOLLA_UPGRADE variable is set. This catches all cases
# of the KOLLA_UPGRADE variable being set, including empty.
if [[ "${!KOLLA_UPGRADE[@]}" ]]; then
    if [[ "${!NEUTRON_DB_EXPAND[@]}" ]]; then
        DB_ACTION="--expand"
        echo "Expanding database"
    fi  
    if [[ "${!NEUTRON_DB_CONTRACT[@]}" ]]; then
        DB_ACTION="--contract"
        echo "Contracting database"
    fi  

    if [[ "${!NEUTRON_ROLLING_UPGRADE_SERVICES[@]}" ]]; then
        for service in ${NEUTRON_ROLLING_UPGRADE_SERVICES}; do
            neutron-db-manage --subproject $service upgrade $DB_ACTION

    fi  
    exit 0
fi

> We discussed this RFE in the drivers meeting and it was approved.
> 
> I'm implementing this check to provide to the admin information about the current status of the network QoS and the FIPs. Admins can remove the QoS from the external networks if needed.

Another option is to assign an "empty" QoS policy to such FIPs, thus they will not inherit network's policy

Adding a new parameter to handle the FIP QoS means to fragment the API. We should expose the same API as with fixed ports. Actually it is the same when applying a QoS policy to a FIP.

About the a configuration parameter to drive the API, this has been discarded by the community always and for good reasons.

If you have bound fixed IP ports in the external network, inheriting from the network QoS, then the administrator can apply directly on the ports the QoS policy. This is the case 2.1

If you have bound FIPs on this network, this check will warn about those ones without QoS. This is the case 2.2

This cannot be considered as a hidden behaviour. This feature is exposed by a new extension and a upgrade check. This everything but hidden.

This is just a warning, nothing else. I'm not checking the FIP QoS policies but I could add (IMO, this is over-engineering)

If we didn't add this check in the port qos inheritance, that was a mistake. This RFE implies a behavioural change and the user deserves to be informed.

IMO, maybe add a config option to make such behavior configurable? Then cloud admins can decide how to do the upgrading.

Sorry, what does it means "no limit"? Do you mean not setting a QoS policy on the FIP?

If the FIP network has a QoS policy, all FIPs will inherit it. The FIP QoS will prevail but for those without QoS, the network policy will apply.

This is why I'm doing this check.
If I'm not wrong you need a tool to, for a defined network (an accepting "port-device-owner" as an optional parameter), set the network QoS policy to those ports. Ok, this is feasible.
AFAIU this handles the case when FIP has no policy binding, and after upgrade it inherits network QoS policy, IMO it deserves a warning

That implies to change the current API behaviour. We don't have this concept of "empty" QoS.

We can discuss the possibility, during some releases, to add a config knob to disable the inheritance of the network QoS into the FIPs. But as commented, the solution is to remove the QoS policy from the external network. Unless you have fixed ports on it, currently the network QoS policy on those networks is useless. And this patch is warning about this.

In any case, as commented, I will bring this topic to the Neutron meeting.

And just to be aware, this could be implemented in a follow-up patch. So far, no change in the L3 agents has been done, [1] is the first one of this series actually making use of this new network QoS.

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/817790

@LIU Yulong:
My first question is why QoS for FIPs and ports should be different thing? If both port (L2) and FIP (L3) are from the same external network, both will consume same bandwidth from that network, right? I don't really see any reason why we should introduce new concept of floatingip_qos_policy as that would make things more complicated IMO.

Regarding usecase which You described - if there is qos_policy associated directly with port effective policy is always like:

    policy_id = port.get('qos_policy_id') or network.get('qos_policy_id')

It's not that max bw will be calculated from both of them:

    max(port_qos_policy, network_qos_policy).


So before upgrade, if now You have qos_policy set on the external network and this is effectively working for ports in that network but not on fips, You can attach that qos policy directly to the ports and remove from network. This should effectively work in the same way as before for You but it will be more consistent between FIPs and ports than it's now.
IMO we made mistake by not adding that inheritance of the QoS policy id from network to FIPs when we did QoS for FIPs initially and now we should fix that.

About the ``config driven API``, IMO, the main problem is how to define it. Neutron has many existing configs which are "enable_xxx", "max_xxx", "allow_xxx". Each of them can change the API behavior. And even more, you can consider ``service_plugins`` as a flag which many times introduced new APIs. It expands neutron API scope. Config options, IMO, are improving the elasticity of a program, especially for a widely used project. You can not say everything can be covered by code itself. But give users some options to choose. For example, Linux has thousands CONFIGs and drivers. Ooooooook, back to this, for this upgrade, the main problem is not in API side, it should be agent side, there is no way to disable such inherition. For the upgrading here, it shoud not break existing running cloud, since they are running fine as neutron current defined. Many times we said to bug reportors, it is a feature not a bug, because it was done in that way from the very beggining. Since there is no code to illustrate the real use in agent side of that QOS_NETWORK_POLICY_ID [2]. Can it be configrable in agent side? IMO, a new agent extension can be an option. Then, if it is not set, let neutron run as it is.

So, Slawek's suggestion can be one solution, 1) set exsiting port's with independent qos policy, 2) remove the external network's qos policy 2) upgrade the code, 3) set the new qos policy back to external network to make this inheriting work take effect. But once you have run a cloud, you will get complains from your upper platform. Because, they need to change the API combinations, they need to take care of the ports. But fine, I will explain to our developers. For robustness, please add a upgrade tool which will make cloud admins can easily set the QoS policy to existing port. Something like this:

neutron-port-qos-policy-set --network <external-network> [--port-device-owner <network:xxxx>] --qos-policy <policy-id>

Or an openstack client command:

openstack network qos port set --network <external-network> [--port-device-owner <network:xxxx>] --qos-policy <policy-id>

@Slawek, for your question, network is a container whose main attribute is L2 segment (vlan_id, vxlan_vni, ...), while ports are resources coming from it. Port has main attribute mac address and fixed IPs. For qos applied on ports, neutron mostly limit all traffic on it, fixed IPs are ingnored, it is queuing, policing and shaping traffic on it. So we consider that port QoS is a L2 traffic limitation mechanism, because every traffic with same L2 sementation id will be limited. Floating IP is a special resource, it borrows the fixed IP from a network:floating port, but it is mainly for L3 NATing. It resides on a L2 gateway port. We want to set each L3 IP a diffferent QoS, while port QoS is limitting everything passing on it. So we make them independently. I guess there are some dissision on the original layer 3 IP rate limit [1] spec.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-specs/+/374506/18/specs/pike/layer-3-rate-limit.rst
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/817734/6/neutron/db/l3_fip_qos.py#34

I agree with Rodolfo here and don't like the idea of adding config option for that. It would be "config driven API behaviour" then so we should make it at least discoverable which means new api extension which should be loaded/removed depending on the config option value.
I also think that warning users in the upgade check and in the release notes should be enough. We may add in the check's message here info what can be done to keep FIPs without limits if needed, like e.g. that user can either remove QoS policy from the external network and set it directly on ports which requires that or set some extra QoS policy with very high limit on the FIPs which have to be "no limit" FIPs still.
For those floating IPs which are intentionally set to no limit, after the neutron upgrade, they are going to inherit the external network's qos policy?

My 2 cents:
* avoid if possible cfg driven API.
* warn the user before update that the FIP will inherit the QoS policy from ext-net.
* let's have a similar behaviour like we have for Ports

Remove the external network's qos policy will disable all ports' QoS inherited from it. So that  frees the ports QoS limitation under the external network. So here are some scenarios before the upgrading:
1. external network has no qos policy, so ports (especially, router external gateway port, floating IP agent gateway port) has no QoS limitation.
1.1. external network has no QoS policy, and floating IPs from the external network have QoS policy. Floating IP's QoS is limited by it's own QoS policy.
1.2. external network has no QoS policy, and floating IPs from the external network have no binding QoS polciy. Floating IP's QoS is unlimited.

2. external network has binding QoS policy, so ports under it has QoS limitation.
2.1. external network has binding QoS policy, and floating IPs from the external network have binding QoS policy. Then the port's limitation will be the maximum value, the floating IP's bandwidth will be min(ports_qos_value, floating_ip_qos_value).
2.2. external network has binding QoS policy, and floating IPs from the external network hasve no binding QoS policy. Then floating IP's will be limited (or inherit）with such port's QoS limitation. This looks like some kind of default QoS for floating IPs. 😊

After deep thinking of these cases, I wonder the real purpose of the original RFE. Seems directly use qos_policy_id from external newtork breaks the case 2.1 and 2.2. IMO, L3 IPs' QoS and ports' QoS should be independent. Maybe this implementation can be done with:
1. add a floating_qos_polidy_id to external network, then ports' qos will still inherit the external network's qos_policy_id.
2. floating IP decides to whether inherit the floating_qos_polidy_id or not by checking some config value.

Anyway, IMHO, for varity running clouds, we should cover these cases after upgrading. My suggestion is upgrading with nothing changed, let the cloud admins read the release note and make some config tunning to decide what should be done. If you have really operated a cloud, some hidden behaviors will cause user complaints😞. Explicit is better than implicit.
Maybe it should tell what it would mean after upgrade
I'll add a better description.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Why can't you just delete such volume attachments in Cinder in that case?

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html?expanded=delete-attachment-detail#attachments-attachments

https://docs.openstack.org/python-openstackclient/latest/cli/command-objects/volume-attachment.html#volume-attachment-delete

Nova shouldn't randomly DELETE volume attachments from Cinder just because we don't know about them IMHO.

I disagree, from a Nova point of view once we've deleted the volume attachment we know about in Cinder *and* our own block device mapping record the volume is detached. IOW when our own os-volume_attachments API returns a 404 for the instance and volume.

If other services like Heat also need other volume attachments created out of band of Nova to also be deleted from Cinder for them to be happy that the device is detached well that's on them.

I'd also suggest that it's on the operators in the environment to understand who or what is creating these duplicate volume attachment records in Cinder.

Yes, it's possible and doable to delete attachments manually via Cinder api.
When our tasks are automated, e.g. via Heat, it's not easy to cleanup bogus attachments. Bogus attachments are not real - it's just records in Cinder DB. So if user wishes to detach a volume from a server it's reasonable to do real detachment and if remain some weird attachments regarding the server and the volume IMHO it's OK to cleanup.

Can you add an example config file, the opentack clients have a bunch of "cyclic" depdencies that will ftbfs (fail to build from source) because of this.

As an example you can look at build-rdeps:

I have been speaking with Charles on this one and it would be really nice to not have to deal with another configuration file. In most cases I believe a cyclical dependency can be dealt with by the dependency being built, ignoring it's dependency on the primary package. So let's say we have the following dependency graph

A -> B -> C -> A

In the case that neither A or C are built yet, A will detect a missing dependency and not build, similarly C will detect A is not available and not build.

We can ignore the dependencies and build either A or C, ignoring any configure options which will flip due to the missing dependency. So attempt to build A regardless of no C being available, or attempt to build C regardless of A not being available. If we can do either of these we can then proceed, ensuring we backtrack and rebuild things with the dependency in place.

Rather than maintain a config file I would rather detect the dependency, Charles suggested tools such as dose-ceve, and attempt this 'forceful' method. In the case that forcing this doesn't work error out as there are bigger issues to deal with. Thoughts?

I have a concern with this routine, and the algorithm as a whole.  It only considers direct dependencies.   What about indirect dependencies? 

src pkg A build dependency on bin pkg B.

bin pkg B is not built by StarlingX, it is merely downloaded.

bin pkg B depends on bin pkg C.

bin pkg C is built from src pkg C, and starlingX does compile it

So A depends on C, but the dependency is transitive, not direct. Your don't seem to be capturing this type of dependency.

Note: I found it beneficial to track direct and transitive dependencies separately.  When calculating a build order, you might prioritize a direct dependency over a transitive one, although ultimately you must resolve them all.

This work is a step in the right direction, but it remains incomplete.  I'll continue to look at it, and we might merge it anyway.  Just wanted to point out that there is moreto do.

I think we lost something in translation.  I was not implying that source package 'b' needs to be compiled.

I was saying that source package 'a' requires binary package 'B' to compile.  'B' is provided by upstream.  But 'B' requires 'C' in order to load, and 'C' is something we wish to compile from source 'c'.  We do NOT want to accept a pre-compiled 'C' from upstream.  So 'a' has a transitive dependency on 'c' when calculating the build order.

Hi Scott,

For such cases that indirect dependencies, in YOCYO and our WindRiver-Linux, we will build all of them one by one. For your example, we will build source package C, then source package B(B ==> b), at last A.

While for starlingx that most of packages are merely downloaded from upstream mirror, I think find and rebuild B is too heavy. And, if we just download binary package "b", we suppose "b" is safe and good. Even though it is runtime depend on "c"(build from source package C), it should just use it as dynamic linked libraries, or other method that will not static use "c", in this case, such indirect dependency is already been broken by this binary package "b". While if "b" is static linked with "c", we have to rebuild source package "B", and then "A". That means, we have only two choices:

A) Suppose "b" is good, thus the dependency between "A" and "C" has already been broken by binary package "b";

B) Suppose "b" is not good, it contains "c" in itself(for example, static linked "c"). In this case, we have to find all possible "B"(s) and build all of them in order.

Here YOCTO and WRLinux, they contains and controls all source packages by them selves, so they choose method A. For example, even if we just fix a little bug with one single line on a low level package like openssl or even glibc, lots of source packages will be rebuild.

While for StarlingX, I think method A is too heavy, StarlingX just contains hundreds of source packages while Bullseye have more than thirty thousands of source packages and more than forty thousands of binary ones, search package "B" is too heavy. Even more, not like WRLinux, in Debian, no matter build dependent or runtime dependent can't guarantee a single choice, some times we can see the dependent has "|", it can depend on "a" or "b", that makes the system more flexible but be sure a nightmare of system maintainers.

So, we choose method B: merely download binary package "b" and ignore such indirect dependencies.

I don't understand how this class is working.   First off, there can be more than one loop, and the lops can share members with other loops.   Does your input meta-data span all packages that are members of any loop?  Or just members of a single loop?

Next, by definition a loop has no well defined start or end.  This code seems to try to build in index order ...0 to n ... and seems to give up on the first package that fails to build.

I would have expected a state variable for each member of the loop.  not-yet-built, building, build-failed, build-passed.  If nothing building, try to build a member of the not-yet-built set.  If it fails, mark it build-failed and try another until there are none left to try.  If it passes, mark it built, but also revert the build-failed state to not-yet-built for all other packages (or at least those that have a transitive dependency on the one that built).

The loop must not share members with other loops, if there are any complex loop dependency contains several cycles, they must be deal as a whole loop, instead of several small ones.

The loop config file must define the start and end, for example, a loop group has three packages A, B and C. The config file must define the build order of them like [A, C, B, A, C, B], that means A should be built firstly, then C, B, A, C, B. Any build error of loop group will block the whole group, and even more, will block the whole build of all groups.

No parallel build in loop group, no parallel build between groups. For example there are four groups, S-1, L-2, L3, S-4. Before S-1 build accomplished, we can't start to build any other groups. They have to build built one(group) by one. The only possible parallel build occurs inside simple group. For example in a simple group, source package A, B and C has no build dependency, thus we can parallel build them.

build-tools/stx/build-pkgs.message: Total packages needing to be built: %d

Perhaps there should be a failed list as well ... to distinguish packages that failed to build from packages who's build was never attempted?

Basically I think there are different reasons for a package 'failed to be built',
we group them all into 'build-needed - successed' because they really 'failed' and the required '.deb' binary are not created and uploaded to repo. I'm thinking in terms of reporting the build failure up to the user.
I would first want to focus my debugging efforts onto packages for which a build was attempted (no missing dependencies) but failed, rather than those that were never attempted at all (dependency not met).

Perhaps it's implied...your build order is more deterministic than that used by CentOS build... the first failure is always the most critical?

ok, got it and I made 'fail' list back. Currently there is not that implicit priority in the 'failed' list. Since the source building process is split two stages: debian dsc creating and offloading dsc build to pkgbuilder container, so this 'fail' subset can particularly refer to those failed packages reported by pkgbuilder. swift/obj/updater.py.message:
I'm worried that we're still going to spend a bunch of time churning the queue.

In the extreme, say you've got no global rate limit and are instead relying purely on the per-container rate limit -- you get to the end of the disk sweep and find that your deferred queue is full updates for a single container. We get to process the first update fine, but then we skip *everyone else in the queue* just so we can re-write their next_action times. We'll sleep (which is good), but when we wake up we'll blow through them all again in the same way, only actually processing *one*.

Yeah, I agree. At least it only iterates once then sleeps a bit, not indefinitely.  But yeah, see the point.

The follow up to this at least can pop_oldest off the priority queue.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
AFAIK DBDeadLock could happen even if multiple workers want
to delete different registers, it depends on DBMS - those that are using table locks.
you mean we use in upstream CI?
Right but by default the DB backends we use will raise this exception in this case, as we use backends with row level granularity.
Yes and in any deployment using MySQL, MariaDB and PostgreSQL with InnoDB tables.
This assumption may not be true if other worker deleted expired reservations of different tenant/project

Yes for several reasons (and I'll this to the commit message to be more explicit, thanks for pointing out this):
1) Those expired reservations will be eventually deleted by any worker that succeeds with the deletion command.
2) When calculating the available resources we (a) count the number of used resources (that calculation will depend on the type of driver) and (b) the current number of reservations.
We retrieve the reservations in [1][2] filtering out the expired reservations [3]. 

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/e99d9a9d0697a21ba7ec84465f415f60041f3767/neutron/quota/resource.py#L340
[2]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/e99d9a9d0697a21ba7ec84465f415f60041f3767/neutron/db/quota/api.py#L226
[3]https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/e99d9a9d0697a21ba7ec84465f415f60041f3767/neutron/objects/quota.py#L100-L101

Right but that won't affect to us. Of course that will depend on the lock level granularity. By default we use engines that provide row locks.

If the lock is at table level, then will have bigger problems than this one, in case of high load.

A system should not have expired reservations in the table. This is just a clean-up method to keep the reservations table healthy.

>> If the lock is at table level, then will have bigger problems than this one, in case of high load.

I think I remember such problems with Galera clusters - that time DB retries helped with this exact issue.

So can these left/not retried expired reservations be an issue for someone who uses table locks?

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Don't we need any sort of testing for this change?
Not sure retry is not needed

This is what I'm trying to explain in the commit message. This deletion command is a way to keep the "reservations" table healthy. By default we should not have expired reservations; this command is just a guard. Any request that issues a reservation will first clean up the table. If we are executing multiple requests at the same time, at least one of them will be able to finish the operation.

testinfra/test_lists_o_o.py.message: Instead of sleeping and hoping we could check if each of the services is running with https://testinfra.readthedocs.io/en/latest/modules.html#testinfra.modules.service.Service.is_running and then have a timeout.

There's almost certainly a better solution than the sleep here (which is definitely an ugly hack). The idea was not just to make sure the services had started, but that they had time to try to deliver notifications before we collect the MM and Exim logs. I'm open to suggestions, but just checking that the services have started is probably insufficient in this case.

Well, more to the point, the restarts and sleep aren't strictly necessary for the test itself, just helpful in producing entries in the relevant service logs so we can observe things like admin notification attempts (and rejections) from the earlier newlist invocations. I couldn't come up with a better place to do this as part of the testing phase in order to avoid applying in production. I guess the proper way would be to do it in a separate test playbook between deployment and testinfra? This was merely a cheap way to be able to double-check that the notifications enabled in the next change weren't actually going out over the Internet and annoying/confusing the admins of our existing lists.
Ya I guess most services out there in the wild aren't actually ready for work once started. In this case the sleep is probably fine and we can reevaluate if the test becomes flaky.
i don't have a strong preference but we've usually done stuff like this in a test playbook, rather than testinfra?

This is the system that allows zuul built javascript website previews to be hosted at the / root because their web frameworks can't handle being at a subpath. Then the wildcard is used with a job uuid to uniquely identify it in a way that the proxy can handle.

Ah, ok, so it sometimes took a while to create a target in prometheus or a dashboard in grafana, because it was triggered by config-change hook.
Thanks

I wonder if this is needed. When a relation is removed, stale data may remain in the Juju controller. However, if that relation is added again, "the relation-joined" hook will update the relation data.

OTOH, I'm not sure how reliable it is for a unit in -departed state to expect that -relation-changed will be handled by the related application (I think, the graph of states makes an application move from -departed to -broken and to "stop"... but I don't think "-changed" would be managed at this stage.

Maybe someone else can weigh in about this.
I also think, as without this all the targets in prometheus remained.

Maybe this is not useful, because it will not destroy the dashboard in Grafana. However, I think we could report a bug in charm-grafana to handle cleaning the relation <==> removing the dashboard. What do you think?

neutron/tests/functional/plugins/ml2/dri.message: The AgentCache is updated/agent is created via ChassisAgentWriteEvent, on which the table property would possibly be Chassis_Private I think.
Right. We create both registers (Chassis and Chassis_Private) at the same time, this is why is working. But let's be accurate and use the correct table, the one triggering the AgentCache updates.

Even if the WaitEvent is waiting on the same table as ChassisAgentWriteEvent (which creates the agent), the WaitEvent might actually fire before the ChassisAgentWriteEvent does, because events are stored in a set() so are not ordered (I have a fix that forces WaitEvents to be processed after all other events here: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ovsdbapp/+/819116). So without that patch, I don't think the WaitEvent ends up buying us anything that the following wait_until_true doesn't since 50% of the time we'll return True here before the agent is created.

This is why I have L324: I check the number of agents in the cache is 1. With the wait event I ensure the event that triggers the cache update is happening (half of the process). With L324 I ensure the other half (agent cache creation) is done.

Hmm.... The emitted error in this patch looks a bit strange.... This patch only modifies documents, but the error says `tacker/tacker/db/types.py` causes `undefined label` error. Does anyone know the detail?
It looks no updates made for may comment yet, right?

As you may notice, this problem might be caused by `:ref:` rules in docstring that have been recently added to SQLAlchemy [1].
After reverting this commit [1], I could run `tox -edocs` successfully.

I'm not certain, but maybe Sphinx considers these docstrings as a part of the rst documents and fails to resolve :ref: rule [2].
If my guess is correct, this is a matter between Sphinx and SQLAlchemy.

[1] https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/commit/605d0d905855684bfe4409532af98f336ae38f82#diff-11f1fd0f775da0862d27dad23b5f9a801df9ea8ade1b55fbd0e84bd888fe4f4dR294
[2] https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/roles.html#role-ref

```
$ cd .tox/docs/lib/python3.9/site-packages/sqlalchemy/sql
 
$ patch -u type_api.py < revert_docstrings.patch

$ cd -

$ tox -edocs
...

  docs: commands succeeded
  congratulations :)

$ source .tox/docs/bin/activate.fish

$ pip list | grep SQLAlchemy
SQLAlchemy                    1.4.27
```

SQLAlchemy 1.4.27 released on Nov12, and it seems that an error has occurred since then.
https://pypi.org/project/SQLAlchemy/1.4.27/#history

The solution has not been investigated yet, but no errors occurred when I tried to use SQLAlchemy 1.4.26 in my environment.

make a separate test for listing, getting, deleting and updating share snapshot as you've done in other patches

True


Testing with details=False is not very useful - below you're asserting that the snapshot has a bunch of attributes - these attributes are statically defined by you in the ShareSnapshot resource, and when details=False, only Name and ID will be set, the others will be set to None. 


Set the details to True, and you could also verify a few things - find the snapshot you created in the list that you're getting back with the help of self.SNAPSHOT_NAME, and verify that things are as you requested, for example: 

share_id is set to self.share['id']
status is set to "available"
share_proto is set to 'NFS'

etc

Isolated CPUs can be identified in the container by looking for files of the form ``/dev/cpu/<X>`` where ``<X>`` is a number, or by cross-referencing /sys/devices/system/cpu/isolated against the CPUs associated with this container.

specs/yoga/project-id-optional-in-urls.r.message: so requests with MV < 3.67 will also be able to query API without project id? seems strange.

It may seem strange in the sense that MV are typically associated with new or modified API functionality. But in this instance, the API themselves are completely unchanged, and the only impact the API can be accessed via an additional URL.
- The original URL with a project_id remains unchanged
- A new route creates an additional URL for the same API method, but without a project_id 

The nova and manila projects took a similar approach, and they use an MV to indicate the point where URLs don't require a project_id, regardless of the MV in the client request.
ack, will fix if another update is required.
shouldn't both endpoints exist to serve requests in backward compatibility mode?

Only a single endpoint is required in the keystone catalog. Clients that use the catalog to look up cinder's endpoint will get the new endpoint that does not include the project_id.

But all of this is separate from the API routes. Regardless of the endpoint in the catalog, there will be two routes to each API method.
- The legacy route that includes a project_id (for backward compatibility)
- The new route that does not include a project_id
same as above, shouldn't we have both endpoints to serve both type of requests?

Same as above :-/ Only a single catalog entry is required, but there will still be separate routes that ensure scripts that don't look up cinder's endpoint in the catalog, and add their own project_id reference to an API request, will continue to function.
all of our api reference is filled with URLs having project id, maybe we can change the url template to show that project_id is optional

I feel that would lead to additional confusion. If the template were to suggest the project_id is optional, then readers would infer its optional regardless of the release. Clearly that's not the case, and the project_id is actually mandatory for clouds running an older release.

hooks/ceilometer_hooks.py.message: Are there any issues caused here since we're no longer checking if paused?
Are there any issues caused here since we're no longer checking if paused?

Good point! This was introduced at a time when this hook was doing way more things and a guard was needed in the case of series upgrade: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/charm-ceilometer-agent/+/605552/1/hooks/ceilometer_hooks.py

Nowadays this hook is way shorter and this guard doesn't seem to be needed anymore. The case where we're doing a series upgrade while the principal unit is paused is covered by charmed-openstack-tester/series-upgrade and I have run these tests in order to validate this change.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: CentOS server is very big image, and very slow to boot. I propose to use the ubuntu server instead. The Ubuntu server already have a real HTTP server configured to reply at the expected URL (http://<floating-ip>/id).

Chuck mentioned his iso contains libnss-myhostname.

Experimenting with pre/post rootfs scripts and libnss-myhostname shows the pre/post script doesn't affect the hostname, but libnss-myhostname does.

We can abandon this change.
Do you think 15s offers enough headroom given you see it take 11s in testing. Would consider making it 20. What is the downside of a slightly larger value ?

If this is being picked to stx/6  does it need a bug id instead of a task
I dont know what the criteria is for picking back to that branch

I think 15s covers most scenarios, the 11s was in a single case out of 7, most of the time it was taking less than one second or around 5s.

We must consider too the test was in a virtual machine which should be slower than bare metal.

It could definitely be used a larger value. I saw mgr-restful-plugin uses 30s (https://opendev.org/starlingx/integ/src/branch/master/ceph/ceph/files/mgr-restful-plugin.py#L97), but in case 15s is not enough we should analyze the situation and possibly come up with new design decisions.

A longer timeout could mask underlying problems, so I think we are safe using 15s at least for now.
I would not have objected to an even larger value.
